newsitem.title: CHINA: China tea officials call for quotas to end chaos.
newsitem.headline: China tea officials call for quotas to end chaos.

text.p: China is considering new export quotas and stronger management of its tea industry to support slumping prices and revive trade, Chinese officials said on Wednesday.

The State Council, China's cabinet, was reviewing proposals for a new trade association to regulate exports and end chaos that has helped drive down export prices by around a third over the past two years, said Wu Xiduan, general secretary of the China Tea Marketing Association.
"We want to stop companies from indiscriminately exporting tea and from cutting prices for the sake of market share," Wu told Reuters.
Although China controlled more than 85 percent of the world market in green tea, fierce price competition by exporters and poor quality had helped send prices slumping, Wu said.

"The situation is critical and many of the problems come from the domestic tea industry," he said. "Tea prices in the international market keep falling...domestic exporters continue to undercut one another to earn more."

Green tea export prices had fallen 34 percent over the past two years alone, Chinese state media said last month. In some cases hard-pressed growers were forced to sell their crops for less than the cost of production, Wu said.
The new proposals, submitted to the State Council by the ministries of agriculture, trade and other state bodies, called for the tea regulator to be made up of major exporters.
Officials say tougher management is needed to boost export quality, clamp down on tea smuggling and stem corruption caused by weakened central management.
Beijing's appointed regulator, the China Tea Import and Export Corp -- itself an exporter -- has lost effective control of much of the trade, they say.
Wu said an association of all major exporters would be able to re-establish order in exports of green tea, a key Chinese export for centuries.

"Since the regulatory body would not be governmental, it would be driven towards sales and profits," he said. "We want the (China Tea Import and Export) Corp to hand over the right to allocate quotas, to make things fair."
Major reforms of the trade in black tea was also needed, he said, but gave no details.
The State Council was also considering slashing tea export tariffs to around 15 percent from 23 percent, he said.
It was not yet clear when a decision would be made on the proposals, Wu said. State Council officials could not be reached for comment.
Spiralling production costs and falling prices have left more than 80 percent of China's tea producers in the red, official figures show.

China exported 166,000 tonnes of tea in 1995, earning $280 million, but production fell to 502,000 tonnes, down five percent compared with 1994. Output in 1996 has been estimated at 510,000 tonnes, state media said this month.
